abstract.text: An image, decoded on the GPU, that can be used to render various SpriteKit objects.

inlineContent.text: object is an image that can be applied to
object, or tiles used in an

. A texture object manages the texture data and graphics resources that are needed to render the image. Most texture objects are created from source images stored in your app bundle—your game’s artwork. Once created, a texture object’s contents are immutable. Multiple sprites can share the same texture object, sharing a single resource.
After a texture is loaded into the graphics hardware memory, it stays in memory until the referencing
object is deleted. This means that between levels (or in a dynamic game), you may need to make sure a texture object is deleted. Delete a
object by removing any strong references to it, including:
Any strong references to the texture in your own code
object that was used to create the texture object

The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.

A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.

A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
